title: ‘The Harder They Fall’ Review: Ultra-Violence out West
sub_head: This revenge story focused on Black gunslingers was produced by Jay-Z and stars Idris Elba, Jonathan Majors, Regina King and Lakeith Stanfield.
body:
‘The details of this story are fictional,” we’re told at the outset of “The Harder They Fall.” But be aware: “These. People. Existed.” (Punctuation theirs.) In other words, there may not have been a specific, real-life Black gunslinger who boasted “I’m lightnin’ with the blam-blams” or a blue-dyed elf who entertained, Josephine Baker-style, in a frontier cabaret. But the Wild West wasn’t as white as you might think it was.
That the actors Idris Elba, Jonathan Majors, Regina King and Lakeith Stanfield are playing inhabitants of the cinematic dry gulch constructed by director Jeymes Samuel (who co-wrote the screenplay with Boaz Yakin) is certainly noteworthy. So is the presence of rapper-entrepreneur Jay-Z as a producer (under his legal name, Shawn Carter). No less intriguing, given the level of gratuitous mayhem throughout, is the presence among the credits of Lawrence Bender, longtime producer-collaborator of Quentin Tarantino, even if “The Harder They Fall” seems less influenced by “Kill Bill” than by the Zapruder film.
